dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news rocking the space industry this week, right? Relativity Space, uh, is dismantling their Terran 1 rocket.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The capital raise will enable the company to fully develop and test its rocket, dubbed Terran 1, and begin commercial operations. Now were fully funded to launch Terran 1 to orbit, says cofounder and CEO Tim Ellis, an alumnus of the Forbes 30 Under 30 list.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, completely shutting down that whole development. It's wild, especially since they've been building it by hand this whole time.

dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] By hand! And it's never even been tested. Designed for a moon launch, but it's just... gone.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.text: He was! And get this, their investors are, uh, not exactly thrilled. Mark Cuban, for instance, he actually retracted his initial investment and now he's *shorting* their stock.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, wow. That's a huge vote of no confidence right there. I mean, they did raise like $185 million total, didn't they? What went wrong?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Ellis now believes their competitive disadvantage was their assembly process. They were using traditional methods, pre-fabricated parts, and apparently had zero success with the second stages of Terran 1.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Ellis now believes their competitive disadvantage was their assembly process. They were using traditional methods, pre-fabricated parts, and apparently had zero success with the second stages of Terran one.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure, and has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, uh, all that talk about their big 3D printers, the "Stargate" machines? Did those... not work out?

dialogue_turns.text: Nope. They sold all four of them! The factory's completely dismantled. He says they'll be forced to produce rockets "extremely slowly" now. It's like, a less automated process.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And their launches were projected at $10 million a pop, which is, um, far beyond current satellite launch costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It's a tough market out there, even though the small rocket sector is supposed to be booming. But, you know, new hardware means satellites are getting bigger and more expensive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a weird paradox. And honestly, no one, not even Rocket Lab, has launched commercial payloads to orbit successfully in this space yet.

dialogue_turns.text: So this 'space race' is going to have a lot of losers, huh?

dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. And Ellis, despite Terran 1 being weeks from its first launch, is already, like, pivoting to 'Earth-bound operations.'
